The larger quarterly report will be issued as soon as the collection of the necessary returns for the period up to the end of December has been completed : (A.) The continued fall in unemployment is again accounted for largely by the continued improvement in coal-mining and the absorption of workers in the Christmas trade.Compared with the corresponding dates in 1923 and 1924, the position at the 21st December, 1925, was somewhat better, the decrease being 66,827 over a year ago and 72,086 over two years ago. [14103] (B.) The improvement shown in most of the other industries during the month was largely seasonal.The Building Trade showed the largest decline. In the Iron and Steel Industry a slight retrograde movement was evident, and a further fall occurred in Pottery and Earthenware.Other industries not mentioned in the above table which showed considerable improvement at the 21st December, 1925, as compared with a year ago, were Tinplate Manufacture, Lead, Tin and Copper-mining and Brass and Allied Metal Wares Manufacture.Industries which are still in a worse position than a year ago are Coal-mining, Marine Engineering, Shipbuilding and Ship-repairing, the Linen Trade, Stone-quarrying and mining, and Building and Public Works Contracting. (C.) Latest Figures.The latest figures of unemployment published are those for the 11th January, which give the total numbers on the registers as 1,221,403. The increase over the position on the 21st December amounts to 119,003,*but the figures are less than those of a year ago by 58,451. This large increase in unemployment is normal at this period of the year. While the distribution of the increase over the various industries is not yet definitely known, a geographical analysis shows that it has occurred in nearly all parts of the country.A. STEEL-MAITLAND.Ministry of Labour,January 18, 1926.
